title: Raab says US should do the right thing over immunity for Anne Sacoolas
text:
The foreign secretary increased pressure on Washington to reverse the decision over Anne Sacoolas’s diplomatic immunity (Picture: Getty/Facebook)

Dominic Raab has urged the US to ‘reconsider its position’ on the diplomatic immunity given to a suspect in the case of a teenager killed in a road crash.

The foreign secretary spoke with US Ambassador Woody Johnson today and urged him to ‘do the right thing’ by the family of 19-year-old Harry Dunn, who died after his motorbike crashed into a car on August 27.

It is believed that the vehicle was being driven on the wrong side of the road after leaving RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire – a military base used by the US Air Force.

The suspect in the case, 42-year-old Anne Sacoolas, is reportedly married to a US intelligence official.

She was granted diplomatic immunity after the crash, which led to the Prime Minister, the Foreign Secretary and Northamptonshire Police asking the US to consider waiving it and ‘to let justice prevail’.

Mr Raab also raised the case in a telephone call with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

The foreign secretary also raised the case with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo (Picture: AP)

The force’s chief constable Nick Adderley said US authorities had been appealed to in ‘the strongest terms’ to apply a waiver and ‘allow the justice process to take place’ after Mrs Sacoolas left the UK despite telling officers she had no plans to do so.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson also urged the US to reconsider its decision.

He said: ‘I do not think it can be right to use the process of diplomatic immunity for this type of purpose.’

Harry Dunn, 19, died in hospital after his motorbike was in a crash with a Volvo (Picture: Facebook)

Following the meeting with the ambassador, a Foreign Office spokeswoman said: ‘The Foreign Secretary met the US Ambassador today and urged the US to reconsider its position and do the right thing by Harry Dunn’s family.’

A crowdfunding page has been set up to support Harry’s family in the ‘campaign to search for justice’ and to help Harry’s twin brother Niall.

The page has now reached its £10,000 target.

Anne Sacoolas,42, is reportedly married to a US intelligence official (Picture: Sky News)

The page, named ‘Justice 4 Harry’, reads: ‘Harry’s loss has left an enormous hole in the lives of the family and they are understandably going through a shattering and life-changing time.

‘This funding page is being set up to help the family and his twin brother Niall through these traumatic times and to build up a fund, as the family embark on a campaign to search for justice for Harry as the legal process unfolds.’

Despite messages of support from around the world, Harry’s mother Charlotte Charles told BBC Breakfast it has still been a very difficult process.

She said: ‘We’ve had many words of comfort but nothing is going to really help us… we can’t start to grieve – it’s been very, very difficult.’

Asked if she had had any contact from Mrs Sacoolas after the crash, Ms Charles said: ‘Nothing. Absolutely nothing.

‘I think that’s one of the hardest things we’re having to deal with is because we have got a name and we have got a face and still nothing – it just seems inhumane.’
